title.value: Aberrant functional brain network organization is associated with relapse during 1-year follow-up in alcohol-dependent patients
title.justification: The title accurately reflects the focus of the paper on exploring the association between brain network organization and relapse risk in alcohol-dependent patients over a 1-year follow-up.
title.quote: Aberrant functional brain network organization is associated with relapse during 1-year follow-up in alcohol-dependent patients

extractions.description: The paper investigates the relationship between functional brain network organization and relapse risk in alcohol-dependent patients using resting-state fMRI data and graph theoretic analyses. It compares future relapsers and abstainers to healthy controls and identifies brain network characteristics associated with relapse risk over a 12-month period.

type.justification: The paper is empirical because it involves data collection and analysis of resting-state fMRI from patients to understand brain network organization and its association with relapse.
type.quote: In the present study, we analysed resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rsfMRI) data from a sample of recently detoxified patients with AD (n = 93) who were followed up for 12 months after rsfMRI assessment.

name.justification: The research is focused on using brain imaging techniques to study addiction, specifically alcohol dependence, which fits within the broader field of Brain Imaging in Addiction Studies.
name.quote: Resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rsfMRI) has revealed aberrant resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) in patients with AD in general.

name.justification: The paper employs graph theoretic methods to analyze brain network topology, making this a relevant subfield.
name.quote: Specifically, we employed graph theoretic analyses to compare functional brain network topology and functional connectivity.

name.justification: A major focus of the study is on analyzing functional connectivity patterns in the brain through fMRI data.
name.quote: Resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rsfMRI) has revealed aberrant resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) in patients with AD.
